trial_identification.studytitle: A randomised, controlled trial of a single versus a four intradermal sterile water injection technique for relief of continuous lower back pain during labour.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: For women in labour with back pain does the single sterile water injection technique compared to the four injection technique provide comparable pain relief

conditions.healthcondition: Women experiencing significant back pain in labour

interventions.interventions: Single intradermal injection of 0.1 ml of sterile water to the most painful point, or central to the most painful area of backpain as indicated by the woman. The injection is administered when the woman descibes the backpain during any stage of labour, as being equal to or greater than seven on a Visual analogue Scale (VAS).
interventions.comparator: Four intradermal injections of 0.1 ml of sterile water to the skin surrounding the Michaelis rhomboid. The injections are administered when the woman descibes the backpain during any stage of labour, as being equal to or greater than seven on a Visual analogue Scale (VAS). The four injections are administered during a single contraction, by two midwives.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Decrease in pain measured by Visual Analogue Pain Scale (VAS)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Pain score of backpain measured by VAS
pain associated with procedure measured by VAS
Pain score of backpain measured by VAS
Pain score of backpain measured by VAS
Pain score of backpain measured by VAS
Patient satisfaction with analgesic effect assesed using Patient Satisfaction Questionnaire
Likelihood to use again with subsequent labour assesed using Patient Satisfaction Questionnaire
Other analgesia used during labour, data taken from medical records

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Women at term (between 37 and 42 weeks) Nulliparous or multiparous Singleton pregnancy Cephalic presentation First stage labour (spontaneous or induced) No previous analgesia Back pain assessed by VAS as greater than or equal to 7 Ability to give informed consent.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Gestation < 37 weeks Multiple pregnancy Malpresentation (Breech Transverse etc.) Second stage labour Pharmacological analgesia prior to Sterile Water Injections (SWI) Back pain assessed by VAS < 7 Any complications of pregnancy or labour (bleeding, diabetes hypertension).

trial_design.concealment: participants are invited to enroll in the trial upon experiencing significant back pain in labour. treatment allocation by numbered sealed opaque envelopes
trial_design.sequence: computer generated random numbers with allocation concealed in numbered sealed opaque envelope

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Mater Health Services Raymond Terrace South Brisbane Qld 4101

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Aubigny Place Mater Health Services Raymond Terrace South Brisbane Qld 4101

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: McAuley Campus, Qld Australian Catholic University Limited PO Box 456, Virginia Qld 4014

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of the study is to see if the single sterile water injection technique is as effective as the standard four injection technique in relieving lower back pain during labour and birth. If the difference in pain relief between the two techniques, thirty minutes after injection(s) is no greater or less than 1 centremeter on the VAS, the trial will have proven it's hypothesis
